para.paratext: Confidential communications between a husband and wife are privileged communications in Georgia.[1] Historically, some courts have confused this privilege with a spouse's competency to testify.[2] The confusion probably stems from an era when the spouse of a party was not competent to testify as a witness. However, it is now clear that confidential communications between a husband and wife are privileged and being the spouse of a party is not grounds for the disqualification as a witness.[3]

The privilege of confidential marital communications recognized by O.C.G.A. § 24-5-501(a)(1) is permanent and will survive after the relationship between the spouses has ceased, so long as the communication itself occurred while the marriage was legally intact.[4] The marriage must be a valid, legal one. The privilege cannot be claimed by mere cohabitants.[5]

Either spouse can claim the privilege, but only the spouse making the communication may waive it. This was illustrated in Georgia International Life Ins. Co. v. Boney[6] where a wife sought to testify about the contents of a note given to her by her late husband. The appellate court affirmed that the privilege belonged to the husband as the communicator, that it survived his death, and that his wife could not waive it.

The marital privilege encompasses more than the written and spoken word. Information regarding consensual marital “acts” falls within the purview of the rule.[7] The general rule in Georgia is that “any conversation or act performed by [a husband or wife] which is attributable to the husband-wife relation, i.e., that which might not be spoken or done openly in public as tending to expose personal feelings and relationships or tending to bring embarrassment or discomfiture to the participants if done outside the privacy of the marital relation, is privileged.”[8]
A court excluded testimony by a wife regarding acts of consensual sexual intercourse that occurred during the marriage under the marital privilege.[9]

A court denied the privilege in a case in which the wife observed her husband stealing cocaine because the husband's criminal act could have been committed without regard to her presence and did not rely upon the confidential nature of the marital relationship.[10] Actions under the Uniform Reciprocal Enforcement of Support Act[11] and proceedings in which a husband or wife is charged with a crime against a minor child qualify for statutory exclusions to the marital privilege.[12] Unlike Georgia, some jurisdictions bar the privilege in divorce actions.[13]

Federal courts also recognize the privilege of confidential marital communications to protect information privately disclosed between a husband and wife in the confidence of the marital relationship.[14] The privilege does not apply to communications that are not confidential and are made in the presence of third parties.[15] The federal privilege, however, is not as broad as the Georgia rule as it applies only to utterances and does not encompass marital acts.[16]
See, e.g., Georgia Intern. Life Ins. Co. v. Boney, 139 Ga. App. 575, 228 S.E.2d 731 (1976).
McCord v. McCord, 140 Ga. 170, 78 S.E. 833 (1913).

This is different from the privilege provided by O.C.G.A. § 24-5-503, which addresses the compellability of one spouse to become a witness against another in a criminal case and not the admissibility of evidence. Under O.C.G.A. § 24-5-503, the spousal privilege against compellability ceases when the marriage is terminated by death or divorce. See Chadwick v. State, 176 Ga. App. 296, 335 S.E.2d 674 (1985).
See Conyers v. State, 249 Ga. 438, 291 S.E.2d 709 (1982).

Georgia Intern. Life Ins. Co. v. Boney, 139 Ga. App. 575, 228 S.E.2d 731 (1976). See also McKie v. State, 165 Ga. 210, 140 S.E. 625 (1927), letters from a husband to his wife, or from her to him, are inherently and absolutely privileged communications and are not admissible in evidence for or against the husband or wife, no matter in whose hands they may be. Likewise, an administrator of a deceased spouse's estate is likewise without authority to waive the privilege.
Georgia Intern. Life Ins. Co. v. Boney, 139 Ga. App. 575, 228 S.E.2d 731 (1976); White v. State, 211 Ga. App. 694, 440 S.E.2d 68 (1994); Brown v. State, 199 Ga. App. 188, 404 S.E.2d 469 (1991).
Georgia Intern. Life Ins. Co. v. Boney, 139 Ga. App. 575, 579, 228 S.E.2d 731 (1976); White v. State, 211 Ga. App. 694, 440 S.E.2d 68 (1994).

See Brown v. State, 199 Ga. App. 188, 404 S.E.2d 469 (1991).

Email written by the defendant, who was charged with murder and related offenses arising from death of her 11-year-old stepdaughter, to her husband, who was also charged, did not come within interspousal communication privilege since the defendant was charged with a crime against a minor child and since email could not be construed as evidence given under compulsion by husband. Reaves v. State, 284 Ga. 236, 664 S.E.2d 207 (2008).
Marital privilege does not apply in cases involving crimes against minors. Pike v. State, 299 Ga. App. 285, 682 S.E.2d 373 (2009).
See McCord v. McCord, 140 Ga. 170, 78 S.E. 833 (1913); Lowry v. Lowry, 170 Ga. 349, 153 S.E. 11, 70 A.L.R. 488 (1930).
